channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chile: 16 Dead, Toll Rising in Valparaiso Fire
item.description: A raging fire leaped from hilltop to hilltop in this colorful port city, killing at least 16 people and destroying more than 500 homes. More than 10,000 people were evacuated, including more than 200 female inmates at a prison.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ukraine Forces and Pro-Russian Militants Battle Over Local Police Station
item.description: Disputed accounts of the fighting in eastern Ukraine emerged Sunday after the military moved to confront armed men who had taken over the station a day earlier.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A pro-Russian gunman stood guard at a seized police station in the eastern town of Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Partial Afghan Election Results Show Runoff Likely
item.description: Official results of 10 percent of votes cast in 26 of Afghanistan’s 34 provinces showed that two candidates were leading. A runoff election appeared more certain.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: From Boom to Rust, Lavish Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
item.description: An array of projects conceived when economic growth was surging now stand abandoned, stalled or wildly over budget, fueling accusations of waste, incompetence and corruption.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The metro system in Salvador, Brazil, is among the costly building projects, begun during the country’s economic boom, that have languished. Construction began 13 years ago, but the system has never functioned.

item.title: U.N. Climate Panel Warns Speedier Action Is Needed to Avert Disaster
item.description: The countries of the world have dragged their feet so long on global warming that only an intensive push in the next 15 years can stave off potential disaster, United Nations-appointed experts said.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: 14 Die in India as Maoists Step Up Raids
item.description: The government has deployed tens of thousands of police and paramilitary soldiers to guard polling booths in insurgency-racked areas. But the rebels have only stepped up their attacks.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Xenophobic Chill Descends on Moscow
item.description: From the moment that Russia’s invasion and annexation of Crimea cast a new, bitter chill over relations with the West, a sinister jingoistic vibe has pervaded Russia’s capital.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A rally near Red Square in March supporting Crimea’s inclusion into Russia featured an enormous flag of the Soviet Union.

item.title: Armed Men Seize Police Station in Eastern Ukraine City
item.description: The attackers, wearing camouflage, looted the building in Slovyansk of weapons, as pro-Russian militias stepped up pressure on the central government in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Armed men wearing masks and camouflage uniforms guard a police station in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk on Saturday.

item.title: Damascus and Rebels Trade Blame in Gas Attack
item.description: The attack on a rebel-held Syrian village reportedly sickened more than 100 people.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
item.description: The White House said that information about major Internet security flaws should be shared with computer and software manufacturers so they can be fixed. But it left broad exceptions for cases that involve national security.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden, the N.S.A. leaker, speaking to European officials via videoconference last week.

item.title: Thailand’s Political Tensions Are Rekindling Ethnic and Regional Divisions
item.description: Three governments have been removed from power since 2006, and for the last five months, protesters in Bangkok have demanded the overthrow of the government and a reduction in the influence of the Shinawatra clan.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giorgio Taraschi for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the northern provinces, government supporters called the red shirts gathered in protest.

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: Lingering Power of Hostage Crisis Short-Circuits Iranian Nominee
item.description: Washington’s decision to deny Hamid Aboutalebi, Iran’s choice for its next United Nations ambassador, a visa highlights the distrust that still infects the United States-Iran relationship.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SCIOLINO
item.media:description: A day after taking hostages at the United States Embassy in Tehran, Iranian students ripped an American flag in November 1979. The political memory of the 444-day crisis is still powerful.

item.title: Crude Oil Leak in China Taints Water for Millions
item.description: A leak from a pipeline owned by a unit of the China National Petroleum Corporation introduced hazardous levels of benzene into a water system affecting more than 2.4 million people.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Tsunami Warning After Earthquake Strikes Near Solomon Islands
item.description: A magnitude 7.6 earthquake was detected offshore near the Solomon Islands in the Pacific Ocean, leading to a tsunami warning for the region.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
item.description: The debate over taking advantage of vulnerabilities has echoes of the Cold War battles of a half-century ago.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker, speaking to European officials via videoconference last week.

item.title: From Boom to Bust to Rust, Big Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
item.description: Projects conceived in boom times stand abandoned, visible symbols of waste and the country’s crippling bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The metro system in Salvador, Brazil, is among the costly building projects, begun during the country’s economic boom, that have languished. Construction began 13 years ago, but the system has never functioned.

item.title: Finance Officials Push for Bold Action to Sustain Economic Growth
item.description: At the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual spring meetings, finance ministers and central bankers also discussed the possibility of new penalties for Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:credit: Paul J. Richards/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Janet Yellen, Fed chairwoman, and Hyun Oh-seok, South Korea’s finance minister, on Saturday, at the meeting on Saturday.

item.title: Coalition-Building Season in India
item.description: The path of the front-runner, Narendra Modi, to the prime minister’s office will depend on a group of secondary politicians, including three powerful women.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Jayalalithaa Jayaram, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu, at a rally in Coimbatore, India. Ms. Jayaram has a reputation as mercurial, ruthless and domineering.

item.title: In Jordan Town, Syria War Inspires Jihadist Dreams
item.description: Jordanian analysts and Islamists estimate that 800 to 1,200 Jordanians have gone to fight in Syria, more than double the number who fought in Afghanistan or Iraq.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: Munif Samara, a doctor and prominent Islamist in Zarqa, said of Syria: “If there is Islamic land, it is our duty to implement Shariah.”

item.title: Police Drop Charges Against Baby in Pakistan
item.description: The attempted murder charge against 9-month-old Musa Khan prompted widespread scorn of the Pakistani legal system.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Salvadoran General Accused in Killings Should Be Deported, Miami Judge Says
item.description: Gen. José Guillermo García is accused of participating in the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of over 1,000 peasants in El Salvador at a time when Washington was supporting the country’s military.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: Gen. José Guillermo García left a Florida court in 2000.

item.title: China Takes On Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
item.description: While China is eager to wean itself from energy imports and coal, its extraction of shale gas is likely to be more expensive and dangerous than elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Huge drilling projects can be seen embedded into farm land outside of Fuling, China. Shale gas has been discovered in the region.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: New Energy Strategy Approved
item.description: Japan’s cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Taliban Factions Clash
item.description: Clashes this week between competing factions of the Pakistani Taliban in northwest Pakistan left more than 20 fighters dead, intelligence officials and militant commanders said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Chemical Found in City’s Water
item.description: Chinese authorities have turned off the water supply to a district in the northwestern city of Lanzhou after excessive levels of a toxic chemical were found in tap water.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
